data.title: Inverse NATO Alphabet
data.solution:
input = gets.chomp
alpha = "Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta, Echo, Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel, India, Juliett, Kilo, Lima, Mike, November, Oscar, Papa, Quebec, Romeo, Sierra, Tango, Uniform, Victor, Whiskey, X-ray, Yankee, Zulu".split(', ')
output = ""
need_space = false
input.split.map{|w| word = w.tr("^a-zA-Z","")
  if alpha.include?(word)
    output += " " if need_space
    need_space = false
    output += word[0].downcase
    if word != w
      output += w.sub(word, "")
    end
  else
    output += " " + w
    need_space = true
  end }
puts output.strip
data.statement:
To avoid confusion when verbally spelling a word, people sometimes use the word in the NATO alphabet associated with each letter in the word.

Help decipher an input string of text by converting any sequence of the below NATO alphabet words into lowercase letters and then combining them <<without spaces>> to indicate the spelled-out words. Note that the rest of the sentence should not be altered!

~~~~~~

The NATO alphabet is {{Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta, Echo, Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel, India, Juliett, Kilo, Lima, Mike, November, Oscar, Papa, Quebec, Romeo, Sierra, Tango, Uniform, Victor, Whiskey, X-ray, Yankee, Zulu}}

testCases.title: Validator 1
testCases.testIn: Tango Echo Sierra Tango India November Golf!

testCases.title: Test 2
testCases.testIn: I see a Delta Oscar Golf.

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testIn: That's not a dog, that's a Charlie Alpha Tango Foxtrot India Sierra Hotel!
testCases.testOut: That's not a dog, that's a catfish!

testCases.title: Test 3
testCases.testIn: This one deserves Charlie Oscar November Golf Romeo Alpha Tango Uniform Lima Alpha Tango India Oscar November Sierra, I think!
testCases.testOut: This one deserves congratulations, I think!

testCases.title: Validator 3
testCases.testIn: Hotel India Papa Papa Oscar Papa Oscar Tango Oscar Mike Oscar November Sierra Tango Romeo Oscar Sierra Echo Sierra Quebec Uniform India Papa Papa Echo Delta Alpha Lima India Oscar Papa Hotel Oscar Bravo India Alpha

testCases.title: Test 4
testCases.testIn: Okay. I copy those, and I'll give you our percentages now: Alpha 82, Bravo 84, Cocoa 85, Delta 87. Over.
testCases.testOut: Okay. I copy those, and I'll give you our percentages now: a 82, b 84, Cocoa 85, d 87. Over.

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testIn: We have everything covered from Alpha to Zulu, don't Whiskey Oscar Romeo Romeo Yankee about a thing!
testCases.testOut: We have everything covered from a to z, don't worry about a thing!

testCases.title: Test 5
testCases.testIn: That's a Whiskey Alpha Sierra Tango Echo of my Tango India Mike Echo and whiskey!
testCases.testOut: That's a waste of my time and whiskey!

testCases.title: Validator 5
testCases.testIn: This Tango Alpha Kilo Echo Sierra so much Lima Oscar November Golf Echo Romeo than just Tango Alpha Lima Kilo India November Golf! I guess it Tango Alpha Kilo Echo Sierra two to tango!
testCases.testOut: This takes so much longer than just talking! I guess it takes two to tango!

data.constraints: None of the NATO alphabet words will appear in the sentences un-capitalized, meaning you always know they are used for spelling.
data.stubGenerator:
read input:string(400)
write Decode - Alpha Bravo Charlie Delta Echo Foxtrot Golf Hotel India Juliett Kilo Lima Mike November Oscar Papa Quebec Romeo Sierra Tango Uniform Victor Whiskey X-ray Yankee Zulu
data.inputDescription: <<One Line:>> A sentence [[input]] including at least one sequence of NATO alphabet words (always capitalized).
data.outputDescription: <<One Line:>> The same sentence but with all the sequences of NATO alphabet words replaced by the words they spell (in lowercase). Maintain former punctuation and spaces (other than those between NATO words).

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

To avoid confusion when verbally spelling a word, people sometimes use the word in the NATO alphabet associated with each letter in the word.

Help decipher an input string of text by converting any sequence of the below NATO alphabet words into lowercase letters and then combining them without spaces to indicate the spelled-out words. Note that the rest of the sentence should not be altered!

~~~~~~

The NATO alphabet is Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, Delta, Echo, Foxtrot, Golf, Hotel, India, Juliett, Kilo, Lima, Mike, November, Oscar, Papa, Quebec, Romeo, Sierra, Tango, Uniform, Victor, Whiskey, X-ray, Yankee, Zulu
Input
One Line: A sentence input including at least one sequence of NATO alphabet words (always capitalized).
Output
One Line: The same sentence but with all the sequences of NATO alphabet words replaced by the words they spell (in lowercase). Maintain former punctuation and spaces (other than those between NATO words).
Constraints
None of the NATO alphabet words will appear in the sentences un-capitalized, meaning you always know they are used for spelling.
Example
Input
Hotel Echo Lima Lima Oscar!
Output
hello!
